Decaf Editor API

Welcome to Decaf, the Java IDE for non-programmers.

See:
          Description

Decaf
com.bitwise.decaf.editor This package contains the foundation of the Decaf editor, including all user interface components for code constructs up to but excluding the contents of method bodies (those are found in the grammar package).
com.bitwise.decaf.editor.grammar This package contains the user interface foundation for the contents of method bodies.

 
Libraries
org.hs.generator This Java code generating package is designed for both static and dynamic (especially interactive) clients.
org.hs.jfc This package contains alternatives to some of the cumbersome facilities of the JFC.

 

Welcome to Decaf, the Java IDE for non-programmers. This project provides a point-and-click interface to the complete Java programming language, and includes numerous facilities for assisting the user in understanding their options and implementing them in correct and reliable ways. The user interface components have all been designed for customization, such that language features may be hidden or provided with limitations to simplify the user experience. Almost the entire user interface can in this way be targeted to a particular user base. A Decaf user should never be required to turn away from the IDE to find information that is required to make progress in their coding effort. All necessary documentation and tools are available and attached to the context in which they are needed, including the JDK API and a comprehensive compiler manual.

Furthermore, Decaf is specially organized for integration into native applications, such that users may customize and automate the operations of their shrink-wrap software through the integration of Decaf plugins. This provides substantial benefit to both the end user and the application developer. The user gains access to the entire JDK library in a context that is non-threatening and remarkably efficient. The developer gains the luxury of simply exposing a Decaf interface to their customizable application components, instead of laboriously coding menus and dialogs that will only serve a limited portion of the users' potential needs.

All that being said, let me take one step back and explain that this version of Decaf is considered a prototype and does not entirely live up to the previous talk. Most of the internal and user interface structure is sufficient for a beta release; it supports the implementation of all the aforementioned features. But I've only coded roughly one third of those features, and there are a few small areas that require overhaul before proceeding. The user interface is thin and rough; it needs to be filled out, groomed and tidied. And last but not least, Decaf is currently using a compiler that is protected under the GNU Public License, which poses obvious business limitations. Other compilers with more lenient licenses have been identified, and can be easily (but labriously) integrated into the Decaf as a part of beta construction.
